coredata.dc:title: Structure of silver microclusters
coredata.dc:creator: Montano, P.A.
Zhao, J.
Ramanathan, M.
Shenoy, G.K.
Schulze, W.
Urban, J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We have studied the structure of Ag microclusters using EXAFS. The measurements were performed over a wide range of cluster sizes at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS), beam line X-18B. The clusters were prepared using the gas aggregation technique and isolated in solid argon at 4.2 K. A strong contraction of the interatomic distances was observed for Ag dimers and multimers. Clusters larger than a mean diameter of 20 Å show a small contraction of the nearest-neighbor distance and a structure consistent with an fcc lattice. By contrast, microclusters between 9 and 16 Å show a small nearest-neighbor expansion and a strong reduction or absence of higher-order shells in the EXAFS spectra. This suggests a different crystallographic structure for these Ag microclusters.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 164, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 December 1989 The properties of small clusters lie between the well established domains of atomic and molecular phys- ics and that of condensed matter. From a techno- logical point of view, it is important to understand the properties of microclusters and their relation to catalysis, information storage, photographic and electronic imaging, microcircuitry, and the produc- tion of better-quality thin films, to name a few ap- plications. It is crucial to understand how the elec- tronic and structural properties change as atoms come together to form dimers, trimers, microclusters, and so on, until finally a large unit with the full char- acteristics of the bulk emerges. In small clusters the surface atoms represent a large fraction of the ma- terial, and they are expected to play a fundamental role in determining the crystallographic and elec- tronic properties of the cluster. It is important to de- termine the geometrical shape and bond lengths of such small aggregates of atoms. This knowledge is necessary to establish a foundation for reliable the- oretical calculations, and to supply information on possible structural phase transformations occurring as a function of cluster size. Optical spectroscopy [1] and mass spectrometry [2] have been two of the ma- jor tools employed in the study of small clusters but they offer limited structural information. Recent ad- vances in spectroscopic techniques have allowed a more systematic probing of the variation in elec- tronic properties with cluster size [3]. The development of new methods to produce well defined microclusters of metals and semiconductors has facilitated the study of the physical properties of such systems. Finding the crystallographic structure of microclusters is a crucial and challenging prob- lem. Only a limited number of techniques have been employed to characterize small clusters: electron dif- fraction [4], extended X-ray absorption fine struc- ture (EXAFS) [5 7], and STM [8] in recent times. The advent of synchrotron radiation sources has opened new opportunities to perform structural studies of microclusters. In previous years we have employed such sources to study metal clusters iso- lated in rare gas solids [5,6]. In the present work we report a detailed study of the structure of silver clusters as a function of size. EXAFS was used as a structural probe to study the local environment of the silver atoms in the clusters. We have extended our measurements over a wide range of sizes, ranging from two to several hundred atoms. One needs a more specific terminology to dif 126 0009-2614/89/$ 03.50 Elsevicr Science Publishers BY. (North-Holland) STRUCTURE OF SILVER MICROCLUSTERS P.A. MONTANO a J ZHAO b M. RAMANATHAN b,e G.K. SHENOY W. SCHULZE d and J. URBAN d a Department of Physics, Brooklyn College of CUNY, Brooklyn, NY 11212, USA b Department of Physics, West Virginia University, Morgantown, WV 26506, USA C Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, USA ~ Fritz Haber Institute c/er Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, 1000 Berlin 33, Germany Received 16 June 1989; in final form 20 September 1989 We have studied the structure of Ag microclusters using EXATh. The measurements were performed over a wide range of cluster sizes at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS), beam line X-t8B. The clusters were prepared using the gas aggregation technique and isolated in solid argon at 4.2 K. A strong contraction of the interatomic distances was observed for Ag dimers and multimers. Clusters larger than a mean diameter of 20 A show a small contraction of the nearest-neighbor distance and a structure consistent with an fcc lattice. By contrast, microclusters between 9 and 16 A show a small nearest-neighbor expansion and a strong reduction or absence of higher-order shells in the EXAFS spectra. This suggests a different crystallographic structure for these Ag microcluslers. Volume 164, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 December 1989 ferentiate between regions of different cluster sizes. Clusters composed of only a few atoms have to be considered as small molecules (dimers, trimers, ec.), whereas microclusters are small aggregates of atoms with properties significantly different from the bulk (the actual size of such microclusters is strongly de- pendent on the type of element). In this paper we report X-ray absorption measurements for mole- cules and microclusters of silver isolated in solid ar- gon. For comparison purposes, we also report mea- surements for large particles with a crystallographic structure similar to bulk silver [6]. The microclusters were prepared using the gas-ag- gregation technique. A narrow size distribution of metal and semiconductor clusters can be obtained using this method [8]. In this technique, the metal and semiconductor atoms are evaporated from a Knudsen cell in an argon atmosphere [6]. The clus- ters are then transported by the gas stream through an aperture into a liquid-helium cryopump, where the gas is condensed. A collimated molecular beam passes through a second aperture on the axis of the cryopump and is used for gas-phase studies or de- posited on a substrate. The deposition rate is mea- sured using a quartz crystal that is introduced pe- riodically in the path of the cluster beam, The cluster size distribution for large metal aggregates (mean di- ameter above 20 A) was determined by transmission electron microscopy. The sample substrate consisted of an amorphous carbon film 20 A thick supported by a Cu grid. The taking of samples for TEM mea- surements required fast handling (fraction of a sec- ond) to avoid agglomeration of the silver clusters on the carbon, which can lead to wrong conclusions concerning the cluster size distribution. For clusters smaller than 20 A mean diameter, time-of-flight mass spectrometty was employed to characterize the size distribution in the cluster beam. The experiments were repeated several times to be assured of their re- producibility. For the EXAFS measurements the clusters were isolated in argon at 4.2 K, the metal concentration was around 0.1 at% in order to avoid coagulation effects in the matrix. The X-ray absorp- tion and fluorescence spectra were recorded at beam line X- 1 SB at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS). An intrinsic Ge solid-state detector was used for the fluorescence measurements. Energy cal- ibration was performed using a high-purity foil of Ag (K absorption edge 25514 eV). The standard was cooled to liquid-nitrogen temperature and analyzed to obtain the EXAFS phase shifts and amplitudes. For each microcluster sample, several measurements were performed until a good signal-to-noise ratio was obtained from the added data. Details of the method of analysis can be found in ref. [61. Measurements were also performed at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory to test the reproducibility of the results, in particular below 20 A mean diameter. In EXAFS measurements one only obtains infor- mation about the average nearest-neighbor (nn) dis- tances. It is not possible to distinguish between the surface and inner atoms unless the difference in nn distances is very large. Silver metal has an fcc lattice with a nn distance of 2.87 A at 78 K. The EXAFS spectrum of silver at 78 K allows measurements up to the 5th shell (6.44 A) (see fig. 1). We have ob- served that silver clusters of average size larger than 20 A mean diameter show a contraction in the nn distances [6]. Similar results were obtained for sup- ported gold clusters [10]. This contraction can be explained qualitatively and quantitatively in terms of surface stresses [6,9]. We were also able to detect outer atomic shells from our data and this allowed us to conclude that the dominant crystallographic phase was fcc silver (see fig. 1 and table 1). How- ever, we observed the presence only of an for clusters smaller than 14 A (mean diameter) and no higher shells (ann) were detectable by EXAFS (see fig. 1). Two factors that can contribute to the absence of nan peaks are (1) the presence of a highly disordered structure, and (2) a strong reduction in the coor- dination number due to the presence of a large num- ber of surface atoms, implying a different shape for the microclusters than that expected from a simple fcc lattice. We observed that the mean-square dis- placements (p5) in the clusters were around 10 20% larger than in silver metal at 78 K and we attribute this difference to static disorder since the isolated clusters are at 4.2 K. For samples containing the smallest cluster sizes, we also detected the presence of Ag dimers and multimers (trimers and quadra- mers). The samples containing very small cluster sizes show the presence of dimers as well as mono- mers of silver and result in a large number of argon silver distances. It is difficult to find a unique model to describe the positions of the monomer and mul 127 Volume 164, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 8 December 1989 Fig. 1. Magnitude of the Fourier transform of Xk3 for silver metal at 78 K (top). Magnitude of the Fourier transform of Xk3 for 20 A silver clusters (middle). Magnitude of the Fourier transform ofXk3 for 14 A silver clusters (bottom). The figures arc plotted without phase shift corrections. timers in the lattice; but our results suggest that mul- tiple-site trapping occurs for the monomer and prob- ably for dimers too. We illustrate this point in fig. 2, where the magnitude of the Fourier transforms of Xk3 and Xk are shown for microclusters with 9 A mean diameter. In this figure one can observe the presence of small clusters as well as silver multimers (few at- oms). Th peaks above 2.6 A are identified as Ag Ar distances (any attempt to analyze the data using the amplitude and phase shifts of a silver backscatterer gave a poor fit to the data). We have observed sim ilar effects for small clusters of Cu in argon [7]. The presence of monomers and multimers was indepen- dently confirmed by mass spectroscopic methods. The interatomic distance for the dimer was found to be 2.47 0.02 A, in good agreement with the optical measurements [111. This fact can be used as further evidence of the transferability of the phase shifts from bulk silver to the microclusters. Multimers of Ag show a strong contraction of the interatomic distance (see fig. 3). For clusters larger than 20 A, a significant contraction of the nn distance was observed [6]. As the particle size decreases, however, instead of fur- ther contraction a small expansion is observed for particles around 16 A mean diameter (fig. 3). This result was well reproduced in several independent measurements and we believe that this might be an indication of structural changes taking place in the silver microclusters. There is some evidence of the appearance of icosahedral crystallites in TEM mea- surements of silver microclusters, although they were not the only phase present in the samples 1121. The EXAFS measurements suggest that for these micro- clusters the most stable crystallographic phase is not fcc. In general, we expect that for such cluster sizes higher-order shells would be detectable. However, the experimental results suggest a static or a dynamic disorder of the higher shells as a consequence of a larger number of nnn positions. This type of lattice arrangement will be expected for icosahedral struc- tures [7]. In fig. 3 we summarize the variation in nn distance as a function of size. We have assumed a diameter of 4.94 A for the dimer (twice the inter- atomic distance) and 5 to 6 A for multimers (as- suming a spherical shape) for plotting purposes. Three regions are discernible: one where molecular behavior is expected (multimers) with a strong con- traction of the nn distance, a second one where the crystallographic structure appears to deviate from bulk fcc (small expansion or no change in nn dis- tance), and a third where the clusters have the same crystallographic structure as the bulk metal and a smooth contraction of the nn distance is observed as a function of cluster size. It should be mentioned that no significant shifts in the energy of the K edge were detected for the samples studied, which is not sur- prising since the width of the X-ray transitions is large at the K edge of silver, and small energy shifts would be undetectable. Nearest-neighbor distance versus cluster diameter for Ag. All the points above 25 A are from ref. [6]. In conclusion, we observed a significant contrac- tion in the nn distances for silver multimers. A re- gion of cluster sizes exists where the nn distance shows evidence of small expansion. Clusters larger than 20 A show a behavior similar to that reported earlier for large silver clusters [6]. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We have studied the structure of Ag microclusters using EXAFS. The measurements were performed over a wide range of cluster sizes at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS), beam line X-18B. The clusters were prepared using the gas aggregation technique and isolated in solid argon at 4.2 K. A strong contraction of the interatomic distances was observed for Ag dimers and multimers. Clusters larger than a mean diameter of 20 Å show a small contraction of the nearest-neighbor distance and a structure consistent with an fcc lattice. By contrast, microclusters between 9 and 16 Å show a small nearest-neighbor expansion and a strong reduction or absence of higher-order shells in the EXAFS spectra. This suggests a different crystallographic structure for these Ag microclusters.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Physics and chemistry of small clusters
